cheatsheet.title: Create a Hello World SWT application

intro.description:
This cheat sheet shows you how to create a "Hello World" application that uses the Standard Widget Toolkit (SWT). The application will simply display an empty window to the user.
If you need help at any step, click the (?) to the right. Let's get started!

item.title: Open the Java perspective
item.description: If you're not already in the Java perspective, in the main menu select Window > Open Perspective > Java or click on the "Click to Perform" link below.

item.title: Import the SWT project from target platform using Plug-In Development Environment
item.description:
Note: This step requires Plugin Developement Environment (PDE) to be installed in Eclipse. If you do not have PDE installed, skip this step or install PDE to continue with this step.
Open the Import wizard from the main menu via File > Import..., and select Plug-in Development > Plug-ins and Fragments. Click Next.
On the Import Plug-ins and Fragments page, select
Import from: The active target platform.
Plug-ins and Fragments to import: Select from all plug-ins and fragments found at specified location.
Import As: Projects with source folders.
Click Next.
On the Selection page, Add org.eclipse.swt.{platform}.{os}.{arch} (for example: org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86 for win32) to Plug-ins and Fragments to Import: list.
Click Finish.
This will create the org.eclipse.swt.{platform}.{os}.{arch} project which we will need to compile and run the application.

item.title: Import the SWT project from downloaded SWT archive
item.description:
Note: Skip this step if you have already created an SWT project in the previous step.
Open page http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/#Latest_Release in your web browser, go to the latest release build, and find the SWT Binary and Source download for your platform (e.g.: swt-4.4.2-win32-win32-x86_64.zip).
Save the file to your disk; you do not need to extract the archive.
Import the SWT project from the main menu via File > Import..., and select Existing Projects into Workspace. Click Next. Specify the archive file you downloaded and click Finish.
This will create the org.eclipse.swt project which we will need to compile and run the application.

item.title: Verify the SWT Project in workspace
item.description:
Verify that an SWT project has been created in your workspace in the format org.eclipse.swt.{platform}.{os}.{arch} (or just org.eclipse.swt if you've imported the project from an archive).
If not, make sure that you have completed either one of the above Import the SWT project steps.
Click on Click when complete to go to the next step.

item.title: Create a Java project
item.description: Now we need a project to store our own source code. In the main toolbar, click on the New Java Project button, or click on the link below. Enter HelloWorldSWT for the project name, then click Finish.

item.title: Configure the Java project
item.description:
Since our project requires SWT, we need to specify this in the project properties. Right-click on the project and select Properties.
In the Java Build Path page open the Projects tab, add the org.eclipse.swt.{platform}.{os}.{arch} project, then click OK.

item.title: Create a class
item.description:
The next step is to create a new class. In the main toolbar, click on the New Java Class button (or the link below). If not already specified, select HelloWorldSWT/src as the source folder. Enter HelloWorldSWT for the class name and select the checkbox to create the main() method, then click Finish.
The Java editor will automatically open showing your new class.

item.title: Write the Java code
Run your Java application
item.description:
To run your application, right-click on your class in the Package Explorer and select Run As > Java Application. A new empty window should appear with the title "Hello world!".
Congratulations! You have successfully created a Hello World SWT application!
